one-shots/the-last-anchor-of-aethyra/act.title: Courtyard
one-shots/the-last-anchor-of-aethyra/act.description:
Orient the players, establish phasing rules, and provide a regroup point that still applies pressure.If skipped, players lose their reference frame for how Kethrys changes.The scene begins when: Players first enter Kethrys Players return from any interior room If players attempt to leave the dungeon: They loop back or encounter resistance No true exit aligns yet You step into a wide stone courtyard fractured by shifting geometry. Above you, the sky moves in layers, clouds sliding past one another at different speeds. Around the edges of the courtyard, archways flicker in and out of focus as parts of the castle briefly exist, then fade. Light is diffuse and unnatural The ground is stable but subtly vibrating Archways are the only exits Some archways are solid, others incomplete The castle is not hostile here, but it is active. Phased Archways Appear solid when aligned Lead to other scenes Can phase out without warning Open Space Allows regrouping Exposes players to visible shifts elsewhere Failure Mode: Lingering too long advances the dungeon clock None directly The castle itself applies pressure No true exit exists during Act I or Act II Attempting to leave returns players elsewhere inside Kethrys The Courtyard reflects dungeon clock changes clearly Which archway do we take now? Do we wait for alignment to change? Do we try to leave? If players hesitate: Swap one available archway Introduce distant grinding or tremors Escalation Track: Subtle gravity shifts Audible stone grinding Archway alignment changes Advance escalation every few minutes of indecision.If the players act: They retain agency over direction If they delay: Options narrow Time pressure increases Avoidance costs time, not safety. Any currently aligned archway Returning archways from prior scenes Leaving always feels like committing. SESSION CONTROL
Dungeon Clock

one-shots/the-last-anchor-of-aethyra/act.title: 1 Act I
one-shots/the-last-anchor-of-aethyra/act.description:
Purpose:
Establish urgency, demonstrate that Kethrys is unstable, and get the party inside quickly without analysis paralysis.Target Runtime:
20–30 minutes at the table.The party arrives in an open field beneath a fractured sky moments after being teleported by Thalos Aethyrian. In the distance, Kethrys flickers in and out of reality. Each phase shift carries it farther away.The air hums. Gravity feels unreliable. The structure is already leaving.This is the party’s only chance to enter.
The castle appears solid, then translucent, then absent
Sections of stone overlap incorrectly when it phases
Wind pulls toward the structure, then abruptly reverses
Sound echoes out of sequence
Do not explain the planar mechanics. Let the scene show instability.Get inside Kethrys before the entry point phases out.There is no safe approach. Hesitation has consequences.The entry point to Kethrys is unstable and only partially aligned.Offer 2–3 clear approaches, for example (with suggested DCs):
Rush the opening as it stabilizes briefly (DC: 12, Check: Athletics or Acrobatics)
Use magic or tools to anchor themselves (DC: 14, Check: Athletics, Survival, or relevant tool use)
Split-second timing and coordination (DC: 12, Check: Group Dexterity or Intelligence check)
On failure: Minor damage or separation for one round inside, then regroupAny plan can work. What matters is speed.If the party proposes:
A clever combination of abilities
A resource cost they willingly accept
A dramatic, decisive plan
You may allow automatic success and advance the dungeon clock instead.This reinforces the theme: success costs time.
DCs should reinforce urgency, not punish creativity
Failure should cost time or position, not block progress
DCs should be suggested defaults, not mandatory rails
Never require more than one roll per character in Act I
If you break any of these, pacing dies.Use this scale consistently:
DC 10: Straightforward, risky but obvious
DC 12: Coordinated effort, good timing
DC 14: Clever or magical solution
DC 16: Desperate or high-risk play
Avoid DCs above 16 here. The dungeon itself is the threat, not the doorway.Failure does not stop entry. It adds friction.Possible costs:
Minor damage
One piece of equipment dropped or damaged
Party briefly separated but reunited immediately inside
The dungeon clock advances one segment
Never block entry entirely.Once the party crosses the threshold:
Place the 6 visible tokens - the "dungeon clock" on the table Explain that certain actions will advance it
Do not explain all triggers yet
The players should understand one thing:
time is the enemyAct I ends the moment:
The party fully enters Kethrys
The entrance collapses or phases away behind them
From this point forward, retreat is no longer trivial.
Over-describing the castle’s history
Letting the party debate optimal entry for too long
Running this as a combat encounter
Explaining planar rules up front
If discussion stalls, advance the clock and shift the structure.You are not testing skill.
You are testing decisiveness.Kethrys does not wait.

one-shots/the-last-anchor-of-aethyra/act.title: 2 Act II
one-shots/the-last-anchor-of-aethyra/act.description:
Purpose: Apply sustained pressure, teach phasing rules, and force at least one costly choice before the keystone becomes accessible.Target Runtime: 60–90 minutes.Kethrys is a castle phasing steadily out of the Material realm. Rooms align and misalign as planar layers slide past one another. The party navigates a hub-and-spoke layout anchored by the Courtyard. Timing determines access.The castle is not hostile. It is leaving.Kethrys contains six conceptual spaces: Courtyard of Arrival (always accessible)
Grand Dining Hall
Guard Barracks
Training Hall
Throne Room (keystone approach)
Keystone Chamber (Act III only) During Act II: Courtyard is always present Two rooms are initially accessible A third may align later All others are phased out, not erased Players identify rooms only after entering them.When the dungeon clock advances: One accessible room phases out One inaccessible room phases in Courtyard remains unchanged Phase shifts are telegraphed but not fully explained.If the party splits and a phase shift occurs: Isolated characters face solo risks using the table above Training Hall and Keystone Room are always high risk when solo Splitting up is allowed. It is never safe.Use this table only when a character is alone during a phase shift.Guidelines: One roll per solo scene No instant death Scene resolves in 5–10 minutes Rejoin on next phase shift or Courtyard alignment There is no explicit goal.Act II succeeds when players: Feel time pressure Make at least one non-optimal choice Reach alignment with the Throne Room Act II ends when: The party enters the Throne Room The dungeon clock reaches the Act III trigger Retreat becomes dangerous You are managing inevitability, not navigation.Kethrys proceeds whether the party is ready or not.

one-shots/the-last-anchor-of-aethyra/act.title: 3 Act III
one-shots/the-last-anchor-of-aethyra/act.description: Role: Chase, escalation, release of pressure Tone: Urgent, violent, unstable Runtime: 30–45 minutes Trigger: Keystone removed or destroyedThe moment the keystone is disturbed, Kethrys stops slipping quietly.The castle lurches violently between planes. Walls grind. Floors tilt. The containment protocols fail. Something awakens.The Planar Warden begins moving toward the party immediately.This act is not about exploration. It is about escape under pursuit.The instant the keystone gives way, the chamber shudders.Stone screams against stone. Light fractures across the walls. Somewhere deep within Kethrys, something moves with purpose for the first time in centuries.A presence surges toward you.Not hunting. Not raging. Correcting.The castle lurches again, harder this time, phasing violently in and out of alignment.You have moments. The Planar Warden is bound to Kethrys It awakens when containment fails It does not speak It does not stop It will: Pursue relentlessly Ignore lesser obstacles Be delayed, not defeated, inside the castle Killing it inside Kethrys is not the goal.This is a narrative chase, not a tactical dungeon crawl.Run it as: A sequence of fast decisions One roll per character per major obstacle Failure costs time, position, or HP Advance the dungeon clock aggressively here.Present two clear options quickly.The path back through the Courtyard aligns briefly.Pros: Familiar route Fastest escape Cons: The Warden can follow Least cover during pursuit This is the clean escape.A secondary route reveals itself as the castle shudders. A narrow maintenance passage Collapsing Too small for the Warden to pass fully through Pros: Temporarily blocks pursuit Buys time Cons: Dangerous descent Scattered exit location outside The Warden will still emerge later This is the desperate escape.Use escalating descriptions: Floors tilting mid-stride Walls phasing into obstacles Gravity surging unpredictably When momentum slows: Advance the clock Bring the Warden closer Collapse something behind them Do not stall.Failure should: Separate the party briefly Inflict damage or exhaustion Cost equipment or positioning Never stop the chase entirely.The castle does not wait.Once the party clears either route: Kethrys phases violently behind them The exit snaps shut or tears free The Warden follows moments later, partially manifested This leads directly into the outside confrontation.Act III ends when: The party escapes the castle The Warden fully emerges outside The environment stabilizes enough for a final stand From here, initiative may finally be rolled.You are not adjudicating movement. You are maintaining pressure.If players stop moving, the castle moves for them.

one-shots/the-last-anchor-of-aethyra/npc.title: Planar Warden
one-shots/the-last-anchor-of-aethyra/npc.description: Role: Pursuer, final pressure, containment enforcer Type: Medium Construct (Planar) Alignment: Unaligned Mindset: Corrective, relentless, silentThe thing that emerges from Kethrys is not born of flesh or intent.Stone and sigil interlock around a hollow core of warped light. Its shape is humanoid only because that is the most efficient way to move through a world not meant for it. Cracks run through its body, sealing and reopening as it steps.It does not roar. It does not threaten.It moves toward the instability.Toward you.Armor Class: 15 (planar plating) Hit Points: 85 Speed: 30 ft.STR 16 (+3) DEX 12 (+1) CON 18 (+4) INT 6 (−2) WIS 12 (+1) CHA 6 (−2)Saving Throws: Con +6, Wis +3 Damage Resistances: bludgeoning, piercing, and slashing from nonmagical attacks Condition Immunities: charmed, frightened Senses: darkvision 60 ft., tremorsense 30 ft. Languages: understands Common and Primordial but does not speak Challenge: 4 (1,100 XP)Planar Anchor Core At the start of each of the Warden’s turns, it gains 5 temporary hit points as planar energy stabilizes it.Relentless Pursuit The Warden ignores difficult terrain and has advantage on checks or saves made to resist being slowed, restrained, or knocked prone.Containment Directive The Warden has advantage on attack rolls against creatures carrying or having recently handled the keystone.Multiattack The Warden makes two Slam attacks.Slam Melee Weapon Attack: +5 to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. Hit: 9 (1d10 + 3) bludgeoning damage.Planar Disruption (Recharge 5–6) The Warden releases a pulse of unstable energy in a 10-foot radius. Each creature in the area must make a DC 13 Constitution saving throw On a failure: 10 (3d6) force damage and pushed 10 feet On a success: Half damage, no push This ability cracks the ground and distorts space.Phase Step (1/round) When the Warden is hit by an attack, it can partially phase, reducing the damage by 5 and shifting up to 10 feet without provoking opportunity attacks. It does not taunt It does not retreat It does not chase downed characters unnecessarily It focuses on containment, not slaughter Inside Kethrys: It cannot be killed cleanly Delays and terrain matter more than damage Outside Kethrys: It can be fought Victory is driving it off, destabilizing it, or surviving long enough Planar rifts open briefly each round Gravity shifts at initiative count 20 The ground cracks when the Warden uses Disruption These replace adding more enemies.The Warden is defeated when: Reduced to 0 HP Forced back into a planar rupture The keystone’s energy overloads it It loses alignment with the Material plane Do not require a kill unless the party insists.

one-shots/the-last-anchor-of-aethyra/act.title: 0 Introduction
one-shots/the-last-anchor-of-aethyra/act.description:
Establish inevitability, define success correctly, and secure player consent to time pressure and loss. Reveals: The castle cannot be stopped, only shaped Applies pressure: Limited time, irreversible outcomes Taxes: Certainty, safety, and the expectation of a clean victory If this scene is skipped, players will misinterpret later constraints as arbitrary or unfair.The scene begins when: Play starts The party is summoned by their patron This scene cannot be bypassed.If players attempt to derail or delay: Thalos proceeds anyway The situation does not improve Thalos summons you without ceremony. Not to a council chamber or study, but to a space already prepared for departure. The air hums faintly with restrained magic. He looks tired in a way you have never seen before. The party is safe The threat is distant but already in motion Time pressure exists but has not yet begun ticking visibly This is the last calm moment What is not happening yet: No pursuit No collapse No immediate danger Sealed Letter Appears mundane Warm with residual magic Contains the full written briefing Thalos’s Spellwork Already prepared Cannot be meaningfully delayed Failure Mode: Attempting to over-question changes nothing except tone Archwizard Thalos Aethyrian Attitude: Calm, exhausted, precise Wants: Damage contained, not heroics Changes behavior if: The party refuses outright If the party refuses: Thalos does not argue He departs The disaster unfolds unchecked These facts are not debated and are delivered as certainty: Kethrys is already in final planar transit Five of its six anchors are already gone No remaining magic can stop the castle’s departure This information is delivered in writing, not explained aloud.Thalos does not lecture. He does not speculate.He hands the sealed letter to the party and says: “You will not stop it. You will only decide how it leaves.” He pauses briefly, as if considering saying more, then adds: “Read this. There is no time.” Assets/The Last Anchor of Aethyra - Mission Letter.png The spell completes before questions can be asked.The letter states, plainly: Kethrys was once stabilized by six planar anchors Five have already failed or been destroyed One final keystone remains within the castle If the castle departs with the keystone intact, the anchor will tear free, causing a spreading planar rupture across the region If the keystone is removed or destroyed before transit completes, the rupture will still occur but will collapse inward, localizing the damage to the castle’s exit point Retrieval is preferred, destruction is acceptable The keystone is unstable and may resist interference Survival matters; nothing is gained if the party is lost There is no alternative plan.Explicit choices: Accept the task Ask clarifying questions Attempt to negotiate terms If players hesitate or stall: Thalos ends the conversation The transition proceeds anyway Escalation here is narrative, not mechanical.Track: Calm explanation Clear inevitability Immediate transition Escalation advances when: Questions loop Players attempt to delay commitment If the players accept: They enter the dungeon with correct expectations They understand success is containment, not victory If they refuse: The rupture occurs unchecked The adventure ends early and grimly Avoidance is possible, but the cost is global. Forced Planar Transition The world folds The party is relocated near Kethrys mid-transit There is no return to normalcy after this.
SESSION CONTROL
Archwizard Thalos Aethyrian

one-shots/the-last-anchor-of-aethyra/act.title: Castle Destabilization
one-shots/the-last-anchor-of-aethyra/act.description:
Transition from decision to consequence. Convert the Keystone choice into urgency, danger, and motion.If this scene is weak, Act III loses momentum and the Final Confrontation arrives flat.The scene begins when: The Keystone is removed or destroyed The chamber reacts violently This scene starts immediately. No pause. No rest. The moment the keystone gives way, the castle screams. Stone fractures ripple through the walls, floors tilt beneath your feet, and the air tears with a violent surge of pressure. Corridors distort, stairways twist, and somewhere deep within the castle, something enormous wakes. Structural integrity is failing Gravity shifts unpredictably Corridors reconfigure or collapse Time pressure is absolute This is no longer exploration. This is escape. Collapsing Architecture Falling debris Tilting floors Blocked passages Shifting Pathways Familiar routes distort New, unstable paths open briefly Failure Modes: Delay causes injury Wrong turns reduce options later The Castle itself Distant pursuit pressure (foreshadow the Warden) No full enemy engagement yet Opposition is environmental and relentless. This scene is a buffer before the Final Confrontation It exists to drain resources and force choices Not every hazard needs a roll Let momentum win over precision. Which route do we take? Do we help the slowest member? Do we drop gear or press on? If players over-plan: Collapse something behind them Force a split-second choice Escalation Track: Tremors and falling debris Partial collapses and blocked paths The Warden closes distance Advance escalation: After each major choice After hesitation After failed rolls Success: The party reaches open space or the final arena They stay ahead of the Warden Failure: Damage Lost equipment Exhaustion Reduced positioning in the Final Confrontation Avoidance: Impossible. The castle is coming apart. Bursting into an exterior space Collapsing through into a lower structure Reaching the Final Confrontation zone The exit should feel violent and forced. SESSION CONTROL

one-shots/the-last-anchor-of-aethyra/act.title: Epilogue
one-shots/the-last-anchor-of-aethyra/act.description:
Provide authoritative closure, validate the party’s actions, and frame consequences through an external lens without diminishing player agency.If mishandled, the Patron becomes a lecture. Keep them brief and pointed.The epilogue begins when:
The Final Confrontation ends
The castle’s fate is sealed
Immediate danger has passed
Cut hard. No slow fade.
The ground shudders one final time, then stills.
Behind you, what remains of Kethrys does not explode. It does not collapse outward. Instead, the ruin folds inward on itself, stone and light bending as if drawn toward an unseen center. Towers shear away into fragments of pale geometry, their edges dissolving before they can strike the ground.
The sound is wrong. Not thunder. Not silence. A deep, steady pressure that fades as the castle shrinks, pulling its own shadow with it.
For a moment, you can see through the structure. Hallways overlap. Courtyards hang at impossible angles. Rooms you passed through flicker into view and are gone again, like memories slipping away.
Then there is a final, sharp contraction.
Kethrys vanishes.
What remains is empty ground, scorched stone, and a faint distortion in the air that slowly unwinds. The sky above snaps back into place. Wind returns. Sound returns. The world feels… heavier. Real.
Whatever the castle was holding is gone now. Or sealed. Or moved beyond reach. You are left to wonder which. Reality has stabilized
The party is safe, but altered
Time has resumed its normal flow
This is a moment of assessment, not threat.
The air nearby tightens.
Not violently. Precisely.
Space folds along a single, clean line, as if reality itself has been carefully opened rather than torn. There is no flash, no thunder, no surge of magic. One moment the space is empty. The next, someone is standing there.
He has not arrived in haste. His boots rest firmly on the ground, as though it had been waiting for him. The faint distortion around him collapses inward and is gone, leaving the world abruptly ordinary again.
The man’s robes are travel-worn rather than ceremonial, layered with sigils that are faded from use, not neglect. His hair is threaded with grey that no glamour bothers to hide. His presence is not overwhelming, but it is absolute.
He does not look at the ruins where the castle stood. He does not survey the horizon. His eyes settle on you immediately, sharp and assessing, as though he has been watching from much farther away.
For a brief moment, his expression tightens. Not fear. Not anger. Relief, carefully restrained.
“It is done,” he says at last, his voice calm and exact. “And you are still standing.”
Keep this to three beats, no more.Beat 1 – Acknowledgment
“You held what should not have been held. Most would have fled. You did not.”
Beat 2 – Judgment
“The cost was never going to be zero. What matters is that the breach did not spread.”
Beat 3 – Consequence
“What happens next is not mine to decide alone. But neither is it forgotten.”
Do not explain further unless asked.Choose the Patron’s tone based on the party’s performance:
Calm approval
Minimal commentary
Subtle respect Acknowledgment of sacrifice
No consolation
Clear gravity Unease
Warning rather than praise
Hints of future consequence
The Patron never lies. They also never comfort.Have the Patron reference 2 concrete outcomes:
The fate of Kethrys
The wider planar balance
Who will now notice the party
Each is one sentence. No lore dump.Give the players space.Ask one open question:
“Do you answer?”
“Do you ask anything?”
“Do you say nothing?”
Let each character respond briefly or choose silence.Silence is a valid choice.After the Patron departs, go around the table.For each character:
One sentence on how this encounter changes them
Or one decision they make moving forward
Do not allow cross-talk here.Describe the Patron leaving:
No flash
No portal
No spectacle They are simply no longer there.
The world feels smaller without them.End on a grounded image, not the Patron.Examples:
Dawn over broken stone
The road away from Kethrys
A quiet moment tending wounds
Then stop.The session ends when:
Every player has had one closing moment
The Patron has departed
The final image is delivered
Dice down. Session over.

one-shots/the-last-anchor-of-aethyra/act.title: Final Confrontation
one-shots/the-last-anchor-of-aethyra/act.description:
Deliver payoff. Force resolution. End the adventure decisively.This is not a fair fight. It is a desperate stand.The scene begins when: The party escapes the collapsing castle The Warden catches up There is nowhere left to run This scene should begin immediately after Castle Destabilization. You burst free of the collapsing structure as the castle tears itself apart behind you. Stone and light fold inward, swallowed by a roaring planar fracture. Then the ground shakes. Something massive emerges from the ruin, its form half-stone, half-distortion, dragging itself into reality with terrifying force. The environment is unstable Escape is limited or impossible The Warden is fully active This is the final stand. Unstable Terrain Crumbling edges Planar fissures Shifting cover Environmental Hazards Falling debris Surging energy Collapsing ground Failure Modes: Poor positioning is punished quickly Staying still is dangerous The Planar Warden Focused on containment failure Single-minded Not interested in negotiation Optional: NPCs (if previously escorted) Environmental forces acting like lair actions The Warden does not need to be killed to “win” Survival, escape, or banishment are valid victories The fight should escalate quickly If combat drags, increase environmental pressure. Fight or flee? Distract or sacrifice? Use the environment or stand toe-to-toe? If players hesitate: The Warden acts decisively The terrain worsens Escalation Track: Warden enters fully Environment destabilizes each round Total collapse imminent Advance escalation every round or major beat.Success: The party survives The Warden is defeated, banished, or delayed The castle is left behind Failure: Character death or capture Permanent scars or loss Pyrrhic survival Avoidance: Not possible. This is the end. Escape into the wider world Collapse of the arena Fade-out as the castle is consumed Choose the ending that fits the table’s tone. SESSION CONTROL
Planar Warden

one-shots/the-last-anchor-of-aethyra/npc.title: Archwizard Thalos Aethyrian
one-shots/the-last-anchor-of-aethyra/npc.description: Authoritative frame-setter who defines the problem and then removes himself, forcing the party to act without further guidance.If removed, the adventure loses legitimacy and inevitability. Role: Patron, planar containment specialist First Impression: Calm, tired, deliberate Mannerism or Tell: Pauses before speaking, as if weighing whether words are still worth spending What He Can Decide: When the mission begins What outcome is acceptable When intervention is no longer possible What He Cannot Change: The castle’s departure The existence of the final keystone The cost of containment Where His Authority Ends: Inside Kethrys After the party is committed Once the planar transition completes Immediate Goal: Prevent widespread planar rupture Long-Term Desire: See fewer disasters caused by delayed decisions Preserve what little stability remains between planes Fear: Hesitation more than failure Need: Competent agents willing to act without certainty Weakness: Accepts loss as inevitable, sometimes too readily Openly Knows: The principles of planar containment That this situation cannot be reversed Knows but Hides: How many times he has already failed to stop similar events Dangerous Secret: None intentionally withheld; his ignorance is genuine At Ease: Speaks precisely, allows brief questions Pressed: Cuts conversation short Defaults to action over explanation Out of Time: Acts unilaterally Ends discussion and initiates transition If Questioned: Answers only what is certain Refuses speculation If Threatened: Does not react emotionally Ends the interaction If Offered a Deal: Declines unless it directly reduces harm Never bargains for personal gain Why He Matters Now: He is one of the last living authorities on planar containment What He Asks For: Containment, not victory Survival, not heroics Thalos leaves the story when: The party accepts or refuses the mission The planar transition begins The Final Confrontation ends If he overstays: He risks undermining player agency and tension Should he dominate scenes? No Is he allowed to solve problems? No Is he expendable? No, but he is distant

one-shots/the-last-anchor-of-aethyra/adv.title: Adventure Summary - The Last Anchor of Aethyra
one-shots/the-last-anchor-of-aethyra/adv.description:
A time-pressured planar dungeon one-shot where the dungeon itself is the primary antagonist.The players are sent into a collapsing planar ruin that cannot be saved. Their goal is not victory, conquest, or exploration, but containment. Every meaningful decision trades speed for safety, or safety for cost.This adventure is about acting under inevitability.At the table, players will:
Navigate a dungeon that phases in and out of reality
Make forced choices under visible time pressure
Decide who to help and who to leave behind
Manage risk rather than optimize combat
Escape while being actively pursued
There is no room-by-room clearing. There is no safe path.
The dungeon is leaving reality and does not wait for the party
Time pressure is enforced, not implied
Interior spaces change instead of expanding
The primary threat pursues the party out of the dungeon
Success is defined by impact, not survival alone
Players are not uncovering secrets. They are racing inevitability.
Introduction: Patron briefing and forced commitment
Act I: Entry into a phasing planar ruin
Act II: Shifting interiors, unstable navigation, and moral friction
Act III: Keystone extraction, pursuit, collapse, and final confrontation
Epilogue: Judgment, consequence, and aftermath
The adventure contains six primary locations and no filler scenes.
Urgency without panic
Unstable reality
Imperfect victories
Consequences that persist
This is not a heroic power fantasy. It is a controlled disaster response.This adventure assumes the DM is willing to:
Enforce time pressure visibly
Say “you do not have time” and mean it
Let players fail forward
End scenes decisively
Deliver consequences without softening them
If you hesitate to push pacing, this adventure will stall.This is not a good fit if your table expects:
A traditional room-by-room dungeon crawl
Guaranteed clean victories
Long rests and reset points
Extensive lore discovery
Combat in every scene
Running it that way will break the experience.Possible endings include:
The region is spared widespread devastation at severe local cost
The party escapes alive but changed
Something follows them out
The patron is proven correct, but not comforted
All outcomes are valid if the pressure led there honestly.Run The Last Anchor of Aethyra if you want:
A tight, high-tension one-shot
Meaningful choices without obvious right answers
A dungeon that feels alive and hostile
A session that ends decisively, not politely
